isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 3200, 4200, 4300, 4400, 7300, 7400, 7500, 8500, 8600 - ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 3600, 3800, 4000FBC - CHASSIS ACCESSORIES - OPERATION

svcsubproc.title: Air Dryer
svcsubproc.para: When the key switch (63) is placed in the ignition or accessory position, power is applied to circuit 12, fuse D1, circuit 39/39A, connector (2), and a black wire to the air dryer. The ground path is through a white wire to cab ground.

If the air dryer thermostat senses air temperature below 50 °F, its contacts will close allowing current to flow through the heating element. When the thermostat senses a temperature of 85°F, the contacts will open, interrupting the current flow.

svcsubproc.title: Non-Electronic Allison Automatic Transmission
svcsubproc.para: When key switch (63) is moved to the start or ignition position, power is fed to fuse G1, circuit 92D, connector (2), circuit 92D and connector (402) with 3800 or 4000FBC, circuit 92D/92E to the modulator solenoid relay (403) coil. Power is also fed from a splice in circuit 92D/92E through circuit 92B to the modulator solenoid relay (403) contacts.
The modulator solenoid relay (403) is energized when ECM (379) applies a ground to circuit 92F, connector (402), and circuit 92F.

When the ECM commands a transmission shift, the relay coil ground is removed by the ECM which de-energizes the relay. With the modulator solenoid relay de-energized, power flows through circuit 92C, relay connector (402) and circuit 92C with 3800 or 4000FBC, connector (389), and circuit 92C to the modulator shift solenoid (404). This causes the shift to occur.
The ground path for the modulator shift solenoid is circuit 92-G, connector (389), circuit 92-G/11-GJ to starting motor ground.

When the key switch (63) is moved to the start or ignition position, power is also applied to circuit 13F, fuse H1, circuit 97P, connector (2), circuit 97P, and connector (438) to the neutral position switch. If the transmission is in neutral, power flows through the switch, connector (438), circuit 97AU, connector (2), and circuit 97AU to the ECM (379) and the crank inhibit relay (661) system.

svcsubproc.title: Hydraulic Brake System
svcsubproc.para: The Hydro-Max II hydraulic brake system uses hydraulic pressure from the power steering pump. If the flow is inadequate or interrupted, the monitor module is fed a signal from the flow switch, causing the monitor to turn on a brake warning light and start the hydraulic reserve pump to provide additional braking power. The reserve pump and brake warning light are also activated when the differential pressure switch (301) is tripped due to a pressure loss in one half of the brake system.

When key switch (63) is in the ignition or start position, power is supplied to circuit 13, fuse A1, circuits 13B and 90U, connector (47), and a blocking diode assembly (48). From the blocking diode assembly (48), power is supplied to circuit 90H, connector (2), circuit 90H, and the hydraulic brake relay (300). From the diode, power is also applied to circuit 90F and the brake monitor module (49). The brake monitor module (49) is grounded through circuits 90-G/11-G to cab ground.

Battery power is applied to fusible link circuit 90-FL/90/90A and hydraulic brake booster relay (300). Power is also supplied through circuit 90-FL/90/90B, dash connector (2), circuit 90B, fuse E3, and circuit 90C to the hydraulic brake switch (50).

When the key switch (63) is moved to the start or ignition position, the flow switch contacts will be closed (engine is not running) and a ground path is provided from the cranking motor circuit 11-GJ/90-G, flow switch connector (763), the switch, over circuit 90R/90L, differential pressure switch connector (301), and circuit 90K to a splice. From the splice, a ground path is provided over circuit 90M, connector (2), and circuit 90M to the brake monitor module (49) alarm input (49-A). This causes the module to switch the alarm output (49-C) to ground which activates the warning light. From the splice, a ground circuit is also provided by way of circuit 90J to the hydraulic brake relay (300), causing it to energize. With relay (300) energized, power flows through the N.C. contacts and circuit 90N to the reserve pump motor. This causes the reserve pump motor, which is grounded through its case, to run and provide additional brake power (fluid flow).

A signal path, circuit 90P, connector (2) and circuit 90P to brake monitor module connector (49-F) provides information to the module. The module continuously monitors the continuity of the reserve pump motor and its power supply. This triggers the alarm and warning light if the pump motor winding opens up, if the hydraulic brake relay (300) remains closed (provides power to circuit 90N and the reserve pump motor) after the engine is running and the flow switch opens up, or if no power is supplied to the pump motor when the flow switch or differential pressure switch contacts are closed.

When the brake monitor module switches its alarm output (49-C) to ground, the brake warning light illuminates by power flowing to the lamp feed connector (28) through the light, connector (26), and circuit 90T to the module at connector (49-C).
The alarm also sounds by power flowing to the B+ terminal of the alarm, through the alarm, and circuit 90S to the module at connector (49-C).

If the ignition key is in the off position and the truck brakes are applied, the contacts of the hydraulic brake switch (50) close. With the contacts closed, power flows through circuit 90D, connector (47), blocking diode assembly (48), connector (47) and circuit 90F to feed the brake monitor module at connector (49-E). At the same time a power signal is fed from switch (50) to circuit 90D, 90E, and the brake monitor module (49-G). This signal is compared to a signal provided from stop light switch (51) and circuit 70C/90R to brake monitor module (49-H). If there is a voltage on just one of the two circuits 90E or 90R for longer than 14±5 seconds, the warning light and alarm will be turned on.
When the brakes are applied, the brake switch (50) also applies voltage to circuit 97M, dash connector (3) and circuit 97M to the ECM. This signals the ECM that the brakes have been applied.

svcsubproc.title: Heated Drain Valve
svcsubproc.para: When the key switch (63) is placed in the start or ignition position, power is fed to circuit 12, fuse D1, circuit 39/93, an inline connector, circuit 39B, a black wire, and an inline single connector to the heated drain valve.

svcsubproc.title: Heated Fuel Filter With Water-In-Fuel Light, Fuel Filter Restriction Light
svcsubproc.para: Power is applied from the battery feed stud (J1) to circuit 14B, fuse D2, circuit 19D, connector (399) and circuit 19E to the fuel heater relay (431). When the key switch (63) is placed in the ignition or start position, power is also applied to circuits 13, 13A, fuse A2, circuit 28/19J, connector (399) and circuit 19J/19F to the fuel heater relay (431) coil. The relay is energized through ground circuit 19-G to the cab ground stud (2G).

With the relay (431) energized, power flows through its contacts, circuit 19A, connector (399), circuit 19A, dash connector (2), circuit 19A, fuel filter connector (401), and circuit 19A to the fuel filter heater and thermoswitch (N/L). The ground path is through the filter housing and its mounting bracket. When the temperature is 50°F or less, the thermoswitch contacts close and cause the heater element to activate.

With the key on, power is also supplied through circuit 19J/19H to the water-in-fuel module (470). From the module, power is applied through circuit 19C, fuel filter connector (399), circuit 19C, dash connector (2), circuit 19C, fuel filter conn. (401), and circuit 19C to fuel filter water probe (N/L).

The ground path for the water-in-fuel module (470) is not a dedicated circuit. The fuel filter housing is grounded through its mounting bracket and whenever water builds up to an unacceptable level in the filter, the water completes the circuit between the probe contacts and the housing. This energizes the water-in-fuel module.

When the water-in-fuel module becomes energized, power is supplied to circuit 19L and the water-in-fuel light (433). This energizes the lamp as power flows through the lamp and circuit 19-GA to the cab ground stud (2G).

When the key switch is in the start position, the water-in-fuel module is grounded through circuit 19P, a blocking diode (1CR), connector (399) and circuit 19N to the key switch (63) ground. This serves as a bulb check to assure the bulb is operational.

With the key switch (63) in the ignition position, power is also applied through circuit 19J/19K to the fuel filter light (434). From the light, power is applied through circuit 19B, connector (399), circuit 19B, dash connector (2) circuit 19B, fuel filter connector (401), and circuit 19B to the fuel filter vacuum switch (N/L). When the fuel filter becomes restricted, the fuel filter vacuum switch contacts close, completing a ground path and causing the fuel filter light to come on.

svcsubproc.title: Two Speed Axle - With Manual Transmission and Electrically Controlled Axle Air Shift
svcsubproc.para: When the key switch (63) is placed in the ignition or accessory position, power is applied to circuit 12, fuse D1, circuits 39/93, connector (N/L), a black wire, connector (800), a green wire, and two speed shift switch (87).

When the two speed axle shift switch (87) is in the low speed position, power is applied to a brown wire, connector (705), a white wire, connector (244), circuit 93A, connector (462), circuit 93A, dash connector (2), and circuit 93A to ECM (379), thus signaling for the correct speedometer range.

When the two speed axle shift switch (87) is moved to the high speed position, power is applied to a blue wire, connector (705), a tan wire, connector (801), and a brown wire to the two speed axle air shift solenoid (802).
Power is also removed from circuit 93A going to the ECM (379), thus signaling for the correct speedometer range.

svcsubproc.title: Two Speed Axle - With Manual Transmission and Electric Axle shift Motor
svcsubproc.para: When the key switch (63) is placed in the ignition or accessory position, power is applied to circuit 12, fuse D1, circuits 39/93, connector (N/L), a green wire, connector (800), a green wire, and two speed shift switch (87).

When the two speed axle shift switch (87) is in the low speed position, power is applied to a brown wire, connector (705), a blue wire, connector (244), circuit 93A, connector (462), circuit 93A, dash connector (2), and circuit 93A to ECM (379), thus signaling for the correct speedometer range. Power is also applied by the blue wire to a brown wire, connector (709), and a brown wire to the two speed axle shift motor (703). The shift motor will cycle to the low speed position and its limit switch will open, if the axle is not already in the low speed position.

When the two speed axle shift switch (87) is moved to the high speed position, power is applied to a blue wire, connector (705), a tan wire, connector (709), and a red wire to the two speed axle shift motor (703). the shift motor will cycle to the high speed position and its limit switch will open, if the axle is not already in the high speed position.
Power is also removed from circuit 93A going to the ECM (379), thus signaling for the correct speedometer range.
